description: From Middle French defaicte, from Latin defectus (“a failure, lack”), from deficere (“to fail, lack, literally 'undo'”), from past participle defectus, from de- (“priv.”) + facere (“to do”).

entries.meaning: The quantity or amount by which anything falls short.
(mathematics) A part by which a figure or quantity is wanting or deficient.

examples: a defect in the ear or eye; a defect in timber or iron; a defect of memory or judgment

entries.meaning: The quantity or amount by which anything falls short.
(mathematics) A part by which a figure or quantity is wanting or deficient.

verbs.description: defect (third-person singular simple present defects, present participle defecting, simple past and past participle defected)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To abandon or turn against; to cease or change one's loyalty, especially from a military organisation or political party.
examples: Capitalizing on the restive mood, Mr. Farage, the U.K. Independence Party leader, took out an advertisement in The Daily Telegraph this week inviting unhappy Tories to defect. In it Mr. Farage sniped that the Cameron government — made up disproportionately of career politicians who graduated from Eton and Oxbridge — was “run by a bunch of college kids, none of whom have ever had a proper job in their lives.”

entries.meaning: (military) To desert one's army, to flee from combat.
(law) To flee one's country and seek asylum.
